pages:
Technical Assistance Report
Project Number: 40565 
March 2007 
 
 
 
Enhancing the Capacity of Selected ASEAN+3 
Countries for Assessing Financial Vulnerabilities 
(Financed by the Japan Special Fund)

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
ASEAN  –  Association of Southeast Asian Nations 
BIS  –  Bank for International Settlements 
CMI  –  Chiang Mai Initiative 
DMC  –  developing member country 
ERPD  –  Economic Review and Policy Dialogue 
ETWG  –  Technical Working Group on Economic and Financial Monitoring  
EWS  –  early warning system 
FMM  –  Finance Ministers' Meeting 
GOE  –  Group of Experts 
IMF  –  International Monetary Fund 
NSU  –  national surveillance unit 
OREI  –  Office of Regional Economic Integration 
TA                            –     technical assistance 
VIEWS  –  Vulnerability Indicators and Early Warning System for Economic 
and Financial Monitoring 
 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sector  –  Law, economic management, and public policy 
Subsector  –  Economic management 
Themes  –  Sustained economic growth, regional cooperation, 
capacity development 
Subthemes  –  Promoting macroeconomic stability, organizational 
development, money and finance 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to US dollars.  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Head        J. W. Lee, Office of Regional Economic Integration (OREI) 
Director       S. Madhur, OREI 
 
Team leader      C. Houser, Senior Economist (Macro/Finance), OREI 
Team member    G. Capannelli, Senior Economist (Macro/Finance), OREI

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In response to requests from ASEAN+31 finance ministers, the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) supported the development of early warning systems (EWS) against the recurrence of 
financial  crises  in  selected  Association  of  Southeast  Asian  Nations  (ASEAN)+3  countries 
through regional technical assistance (TA) 5986, An ASEAN+3 Framework for the Development 
of Early Warning Systems,2 and TA 6070, Capacity Building for Implementing Early Warning 
Systems.3 Under TA 5986, ADB facilitated the development of a prototype EWS together with a 
core set of macroprudential indicators. The prototype was discussed during workshops jointly 
organized by ADB, the ASEAN Secretariat, and ASEAN+3 members in 2002. Under TA 6070, 
ADB supported the implementation of the prototype by developing software (the Vulnerability 
Indicators  and  Early  Warning  System  for  Economic  and  Financial  Monitoring  [VIEWS]),  a 
supporting regional database on macroprudential indicators, and a secured website for VIEWS 
users. VIEWS was disseminated through regional workshops and installed in the central banks 
and in the finance ministries' national surveillance units (NSUs) of tne ASEAN+3 countries, 
where users were trained in its use.  
 
2.  VIEWS software is now routinely used by ASEAN+3 central banks and finance ministries 
to monitor economic and financial conditions. With assistance from ADB, users have begun to 
modify  the  EWS  prototype  to  suit  country-specific  conditions.  As  regional  authorities  gain 
familiarity  with  EWS  and  as  regional  cooperative  efforts  progress,  regional  dialogue  on 
economic  surveillance  is  gaining  in  sophistication  and  there  is  a  desire  for  further  EWS 
development.  During  the  course  of  regional  EWS  training  workshops,  ASEAN+3  members 
requested further support from ADB for EWS training and assistance in developing a new 
version of VIEWS. ADB was asked to support the activities of the newly formed ASEAN+3 
Technical Working Group on Economic and Financial Monitoring (ETWG), which was launched 
during the May 2006 ASEAN+3 Finance Ministers' Meeting (FMM) in Hyderabad, India. The TA 
concept was developed and approved by ADB Management in October 2006.4 The support for 
the proposed regional TA was discussed and agreed upon with ETWG members during the 
group's inaugural meeting in Hangzhou, People’s Republic of China, in December 2006. The 
key outcomes, activities, financing plan, and implementation arrangements are reflected in this 
paper. The TA framework is attached as Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Although  the  ASEAN+3  countries  are  making  significant  progress  in  reducing  the 
vulnerabilities that made the region's economies susceptible to financial and economic crises in 
1997–1998, new challenges to regional economic and financial stability continue to emerge. 
Ongoing  global  financial  integration  and  innovation  present  new  complexities  to  regional 
policymakers. Large potential benefits for developing member countries (DMCs) accompany the 
evolution of the global financial system, but so too do large risks such as the possible sudden 
correction  of  the  global  external  payments  imbalance,  to  which  ASEAN+3  economies  are 
particularly vulnerable. At the same time, volatile short-term capital flows are reemerging to 
                                                 
1  The ASEAN+3 countries include the 10 members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) plus the 
People's Republic of China, Japan, and the Republic of Korea.  
2  ADB. 2001. Technical Assistance for an ASEAN+3 Framework for the Development of Early Warning Systems. 
Manila (TA 5986-REG, for $150,000, approved on 3 July).  
3  ADB. 2002. Technical Assistance for Capacity Building for Implementing Early Warning Systems in ASEAN+3 
Countries. Manila (TA 6070-REG, for $250,000, approved on 13 December).   
4  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities on 16 October 2006.

2 
complicate macroeconomic management. EWSs need to adapt to this new environment to 
ensure that policymakers remain alert to potential new sources of instability.  
 
4.  Alongside  globalization,  regional  integration  and  interdependence  are  growing,  and 
regional policy cooperation is deepening among the ASEAN+3 economies. ASEAN+3 FMM 
agendas continue to focus on initiatives to strengthen both the Economic Review and Policy 
Dialogue (ERPD) process, which is the principal mechanism of regional economic and financial 
surveillance; and the Chiang Mai Initiative (CMI), which is a short-term foreign currency liquidity 
facility built through a network of bilateral swap arrangements. The success of these initiatives 
hinges on strong surveillance inputs from national governments. Strong economic surveillance 
systems can also provide important support for assessing vulnerabilities in conjunction with 
managing public debt, developing national local financial markets, and other country-specific 
economic and financial issues. However, finance ministers recognize the capacity limitations of 
national  governments,  especially  in  the  smaller  ASEAN  economies,  to  keep  up  with  fast-
changing markets and provide effective monitoring and inputs into regional dialogue. Hence, in 
2006,  they  created  the  Group  of  Experts  (GOE)  and  ETWG  to  explore  ways  for  further 
strengthening surveillance capacity in East Asia.  
 
5.  A central focus of GOE and ETWG efforts in strengthening regional surveillance is to 
develop  a  more  comprehensive  framework  for  a  regional  approach  in  assessing  financial 
vulnerability. A critical component of that framework is an effective EWS that adapts to the 
rapidly developing regional economic and financial systems and exploits advances in EWS 
research so as to ensure detection of new threats to those systems. An effective EWS will 
provide a quantitative basis for qualitative assessment and policy discussion of economic and 
financial threats at national, regional, and global levels. At the national level, surveillance units 
or similar offices at central banks and ministries of finance prepare internal reports that use 
inputs from VIEWS (and, sometimes, alternative systems) and include qualitative analyses on 
issues, risks, and policy issues. At the regional level, VIEWS provides inputs into ASEAN 
Secretariat reports to ASEAN+3 FMM and can be used in various other reports and analyses. 
Indirectly, these inputs inform regional officials' discussions at global forums.     
 
6.  The key strength of the existing VIEWS, including its common core set of indicators, is 
its role both as a basis for common understanding and dialogue and as a prototype that 
participating ASEAN+3 members can be trained to use and that can be subsequently adapted 
to country-specific conditions. The key weaknesses of the existing system are (i) its need to be 
enhanced to reflect both evolving regional conditions and advances in modeling techniques; and 
(ii) the need to improve the capacity of government officials at central banks and finance 
ministries to assess the quantitative results against qualitative assessments drawn from their 
own understanding of economic conditions, and draw appropriate policy conclusions. 
 
7.  Because of DMC capacity constraints, ADB support is necessary at this critical stage to 
sustain and build on earlier success in forging a common regional framework for assessing 
financial vulnerability, of which EWS is an integral part. This support is a key component of 
implementation of the third pillar—monetary and financial cooperation and integration—of ADB's 
Regional Cooperation and Integration Strategy, which calls for ADB to support effective regional 
economic surveillance, and development and establishment of EWS in DMCs.    
 
8.  The success of ADB support for strengthening regional surveillance thus far rests on (i) 
clear ownership by ASEAN+3 officials of the process of building effective EWS in support of 
financial stability; (ii) a multifaceted approach to technical support and training that involves the 
provision of inputs from external experts, on-site training, regional workshops, and software help

3   
desk and website support; (iii) synergies with other ADB economic and financial monitoring 
training programs for ASEAN+3 officials;5 and (iv) intensive involvement of ADB staff with in-
house  expertise  in  these  activities.  These  elements  should  continue  to  characterize  ADB 
assistance to ASEAN+3 EWS work.     
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The objective of the TA is to strengthen regional monitoring of economic and financial 
systems. Identification of systemic financial and economic risks will increase the probability of 
early detection of possible crises and permit timely policy action to prevent or mitigate a crisis. 
Regional monitoring will be strengthened by more informed and higher-quality discussions at 
ETWG,  FMM,  and  other  regional  forums.  The  development  of  a  systematic  approach  for 
assessing  regional  financial  vulnerability  will  establish  a  common  framework  for  regional 
surveillance  and  discussion  of  potential  vulnerabilities.  Moreover,  the  collective  process  of 
developing such a systematic approach will itself strengthen the cooperative experience.  
  
10.  An important element of the approach will be an enhanced and organic VIEWS package 
that adapts to new conditions while still serving as a prototype for NSUs. This prototype VIEWS  
can provide a quantitative basis for discussions of regional vulnerabilities. Through support for 
strong, evolving quantitative inputs into national and regional surveillance systems, as well as 
qualitative discussions at ETWG meetings, the TA will provide significant value to regional 
efforts to monitor vulnerability of economic and financial systems. This will complement other 
ADB assistance (noted above) that targets improvements in qualitative inputs through training 
programs in economic and financial monitoring for officials at finance ministries and central 
banks.  Starting  with  a  comprehensive  review  of  the  VIEWS  package,  including  the  set  of 
macroprudential indicators and the methodological approach, an enhanced VIEWS package will 
evolve as an outcome of the ongoing and collaborative ADB and ETWG efforts.    
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
11.  The outcome outlined in paras. 9–10 will be achieved through three key ADB–supported 
outputs to selected ASEAN+3 countries.6 
 
12.  First, ADB will provide logistical, technical, and research support for developing  a 
systemic regional approach to financial vulnerability assessment, including advanced versions 
of VIEWS, under the auspices of the newly formed ASEAN+3 ETWG. Specifically, in support of  
the semiannual ETWG meetings, beginning in the second half of 2007, ADB will support four 
workshops. The agenda of the workshops, which will likely include inputs from both external and 
internal (ADB) EWS experts, will be mutually agreed upon with ETWG. The topic, structure, and 
                                                 
5  Related ADB assistance includes technical support for NSUs and training of Ministry of Finance and Central Bank 
officials  under ADB. 2006. Technical Assistance for Technical Training and Capacity Building for Selected 
ASEAN+3 Countries on Regional Economic and Financial Monitoring. Manila (TA 6342-REG, for $900,000, 
approved on 12 September); and ADB. 2005. Technical Assistance for Strengthening Economic and Financial 
Monitoring in Selected ASEAN+3 Countries. Manila (TA 6280-REG, for $600,000, approved on 2 December). 
These TAs provide technical support and general training in surveillance to relevant officials (including in the use of 
VIEWS software and interpretation of VIEWS technical reports) but do not provide specific technical support to 
VIEWS  users  or  direct  support  to  the  ETWG  for  systematic  improvements  in  the  surveillance  framework 
underpinning regional cooperation.  
6 Cambodia, People's Republic of China, Lao People's Democratic Republic, Indonesia, Malaysia, Philippines, 
Thailand, and Viet Nam.

4 
inputs for the first workshop were expected to be agreed upon at the February 2007 ETWG 
meeting. A comprehensive review of the current VIEWS package, an exploration of various 
software  enhancements  requested  by  governments  (such  as  adaptation  to  use  with  debt 
management systems), as well as its use by NSUs will likely be included in the first workshop 
agenda. In a possible progression, the second workshop could focus on options for enhancing 
the VIEWs package; the third could set out a proposed enhanced prototype VIEWS package for 
comment, refinement, and adoption by ETWG; and the fourth could give a demonstration of the 
finished prototype.    
 
13.  Second, ADB will facilitate cooperation among and between national and international 
agencies to enhance both the availability of consistent data sources and the development of 
macroprudential indicators as well as their effective use in a comprehensive regional effort to 
monitor economic and financial systems and assess potential vulnerabilities. The mechanism 
for this effort would be a workshop. Targeting wider participation, the workshop will be held 
separately from ETWG meetings and would ideally include participants from ASEAN+3 finance 
ministries,  central  banks,  and  statistical  offices.  Other  international  agencies  such  as 
International Monetary Fund (IMF) and Bank for International Settlements (BIS) may also be 
invited.  
 
14.  Third, ADB will undertake ongoing maintenance and upgrading of the VIEWS software 
(including revision of the users’ manual) and secured VIEWS website, training of officials in 
NSUs and in relevant user departments of central banks, and technical support for adaptation of 
VIEWS to specific country conditions.   
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The total cost of the TA is $700,000, of which $600,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. The governments of the 
participating countries will provide counterpart contributions in the form of salaries of counterpart 
staff, office accommodation, equipment, and other overhead expenses in kind. Details of the 
cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.   Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  ADB will be the TA Executing Agency and its Office of Regional Economic Integration 
(OREI) will execute the TA in close collaboration with ETWG. OREI and ETWG will jointly plan 
and organize the four ETWG workshops. OREI, in consultation with ETWG, will organize the 
workshop on macroprudential indicators. OREI will manage the activities related to maintaining 
the secured VIEWS website and supporting VIEWS users. To provide inputs for the workshop, 
international consultants will be engaged. To support TA activities, especially ongoing VIEWS 
support, national consultants will be engaged. A no-objection letter will be obtained prior to 
commencing or financing TA activities in the territory of the participating DMCs. 
 
17.  The TA will require approximately 11 person-months of international and 24 person-
months of national consulting services. The TA will be implemented over 24 months, starting in 
April  2007  and  ending  in  March  2009.  All  consultants  will  be  selected  and  engaged  in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2006, as amended from time to 
time). The scope of work and outline terms of reference are in Appendix 3.  
 
18.  Research inputs prepared for the workshops will subsequently be peer-reviewed and 
published as ADB working papers. The enhanced VIEWS software, revised VIEWS manual,

5   
and revised indicators will be available to users on the secured VIEWS website. The outcome of 
the  assistance  will  be  evaluated  based  on  feedback  from  workshop  participants  and  from 
VIEWS users.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis for 
Enhancing the Capacity of Selected ASEAN+3 Countries for Assessing Financial Vulnerabilities, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.

6      Appendix 1

8      Appendix 2    
COST ESTIMATES AND FINANCING PLAN

Appendix 3  9  
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Economists (11 person-months) 
1.  The international economists will be economists familiar with analysis and applications of 
early earning systems (EWS), with expertise in economic and financial surveillance, and a deep 
knowledge of the East Asian region. In consultation with the Office of Regional Economic 
Integration (OREI) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), the consultants will 
 
(i)  provide research-quality background papers, possibly in collaboration with OREI 
staff,  guided  by  terms  of  reference  jointly  agreed  upon  with  OREI  and  the 
Technical Working Group on Economic and Financial Monitoring (ETWG); submit 
the draft papers for review by OREI staff and ETWG members; present those 
papers  at  the  EWS  workshops  to  be  organized  in  conjunction  with  ETWG 
meetings; and submit the papers for peer review as ADB working papers, and 
revise as needed;  
(ii)  train the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN)+3 officials on-site or 
through workshops to operate the enhanced Vulnerability Indicators and Early 
Warning System for Economic and Financial Monitoring (VIEWS); and  
(iii)  provide any other EWS-related input in regional workshops, training programs, or 
research activities as requested by OREI staff and ETWG members. 
 
B.  National Consultants (24 person-months) 
2.  One national consultant will be a computer programmer/software specialist. Under the 
supervision of OREI staff and in collaboration with the international consultants, the national 
consultant will  assist in  enhancing  user  support  for  VIEWS,  including  revision  of  the  user 
manual and other tasks. 
 
3.  Other national consultants will be economists or statisticians with extensive experience 
in economic and financial data processing and analysis, familiarity with the East Asian region, 
strong communication skills (including English), and proficiency in using software with standard 
applications. Under the supervision of OREI staff and the international consultants, the national 
consultants  will  assist  in  (i)  collecting  and  processing  economic  and  financial  data;  (ii) 
responding to user requests for support; and (iii) as needed, other aspects of implementing 
VIEWS.
